1.text: Fill a small vase or tall jar about halfway with water.

2.text: Trim the bottom 1 in (2.5 cm) off the basil stems.

3.text: Put the basil in the jar and store it at around 65 °F (18 °C).

4.text: Place a produce bag loosely over the basil bouquet, if desired.

5.text: Change the water every 1-2 days to get up to 7 days of usable basil.

6.text: Pluck off the leaves and rinse them under cool water.

7.text: Pat the leaves dry gently with paper towels.

8.text: Wrap the leaves loosely in dry paper towels.

9.text: Seal the basil in a zip-close bag and put it in the fridge.

10.text: Use the basil within 12 (maybe 24) hours for the best results.

11.text: Prepare a pot of boiling water and an ice bath.

12.text: Blanch the plucked and rinsed leaves for 2 seconds.

13.text: Move the blanched leaves immediately to an ice bath.

14.text: Move the cooled leaves from the ice bath to paper towels for drying.

15.text: Lay a single layer of leaves on a sheet of wax paper, then repeat.

16.text: Slide the layered leaves into a freezer bag to store for up to 6 months.

17.text: Buy a small potted basil from your grocer’s produce department.

18.text: Set the pot on a windowsill that gets ample sunlight.

19.text: Keep the potting medium evenly moist with regular watering.

20.text: Pluck off fresh leaves right when you need them.

21.text: Replace it with a new potted basil every several weeks, as needed.
